page.title:
Changes in Direction
Changes in Direction
page.enlisting:
•Change in apparent speed possible from change in direction even if  constant •Nonthermal luminosity seems to be related to direction of jet •Changes amplified greatly by projection effects •Velocity seems ballistic in some jets but seems to follow twisting jet in many others

page.title:
The Core of Blazar Jets
The Core of Blazar Jets
page.enlisting:
a. Frequencies below ~ 40 GHz:  ~ 1 surface (deeper at higher frequencies) b. At higher frequencies, perhaps some lower frequencies: Conical standing shock (Daly & Marscher 1988) - Reproduces polarization pattern if randomly oriented B field is compressed by conical shock (Cawthorne 2006; e.g.; non-EGRET BL Lac object 1803+784 shown below) c. Even higher frequencies (~300 GHz): End of zone of flow acceleration - Where Doppler factor reaches asymptotic value

Jorstad et al. (2001): In 10 out of 23 cases

page.title:
EGRET/VLBI: Likely Site(s) of Gamma-ray Emission
EGRET/VLBI: Likely Site(s) of Gamma-ray Emission
page.enlisting:
- Method for testing: (1) Well-sampled (monthly) time sequences of 43 GHz VLBI 1. Moving shock waves = superluminal knots 2. Standing (oblique/conical) shocks = core & other stationary features Signature: steady but typically low polarization, usually parallel to jet axis 3. Combination of the two (as in M87; Cheung et al. 2007, ApJL, submitted) - Method for testing: (1) Well-sampled (monthly) time sequences of 43 GHz VLBI
- Method for testing: (1) Well-sampled (monthly) time sequences of 43 GHz VLBI
1. Moving shock waves = superluminal knots 2. Standing (oblique/conical) shocks = core & other stationary features Signature: steady but typically low polarization, usually parallel to jet axis 3. page.title:
Cryptic Guide to VLBI Observations
Cryptic Guide to VLBI Observations
page.ref:
sources): www.physics.purdue.edu/astro/MOJAVE and ~1000 sources at 5 GHz from VIPS (G. Taylor, UNM) in the future
sources): www.physics.purdue.edu/astro/MOJAVE and ~1000 sources at 5
GHz from VIPS (G. Taylor, UNM) in the future
page.enlisting:
Frequencies lower than ~ 15 GHz: - Sensitive but relatively coarse resolution (>0.5 mas), inner jet opaque → Good for surveys but need to wait to see moving knots - Images of > 100 sources at 15 GHz available at MOJAVE website (~100 43 & 22 GHz (VLBA, add Effelsberg et al. for better resolution): + Fine resolution (0.1-0.2 mas), can see deeper into jet → see knots shortly after ejection, get apparent speeds & dates of ejection − Sensitive enough only for > 1 Jy blazars, 0.1 Jy with phase referencing + Need to observe at least once per month to follow knots - Images of 29 blazars will be available at www.bu.edu 86 GHz (Global Mm-VLBI Array): + Highest non-experimental frequency + Finest resolution (40 as) − Lowest sensitivity → probes core region, not much else − Poor time coverage - twice per year (unless core brighter than a few Jy so Frequencies lower than ~ 15 GHz: - Sensitive but relatively coarse resolution (>0.5 mas), inner jet opaque → Good for surveys but need to wait to see moving knots - Images of > 100 sources at 15 GHz available at MOJAVE website (~100

Number of Objects in a VLBA Session
Number of Objects in a VLBA Session
